reviewText:
This is a fun game. Think Portal, if Portal were also Psychonauts.

You play as Dawn, an acrobat with the ability to merge into her own shadow - and a curious inability to directly see or be seen by anyone other than Didi. This at first seems like simply an odd quirk, until the ending draws attention to it and refuses to actually offer explanation.

The controls are good, if a little more responsive on the camera than I expected. The shadow-merging mechanic could use a little more polish - I often found myself popping out of the wall without being able to figure out why, and occasionally ended up across the room from where I had been a moment prior.

The story is simple, which simply leaves more room to showcase the central mechanic and the world. Most characters (seen via projected shadows) talk with their hands a lot, presumably so you can tell who's talking as lips' shadows are very small.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Contrast is like Bioshock Infinite, but a lot shorter.

It revolves around that you as a player can fuse into shadows and move around in it, and by doing so clearing obstacles. You can mess around with objects and light sources to help you with the puzzles, and its a very interesting concept. But in some parts I feel the platforming in the shadows are a little bit clunky, and I have no idea why I would just jump out of the shadows sometimes without hitting any obstacles (well I assume i didnt hit anything).

Music is great, voice acting is great, story can be better, controls are a bit awkward at times for both keyboard and controller,

Good game overall, short but worth it. No brainer if its on discount.

reviewText:
Game was really short, not too difficult, and maybe a bit glitchy.

It had an interesting concept but the puzzles aren't that difficult to figure out once you figure out all the items at your disposal.  You could do alot with the game but it didn't really last long enough to really amaze me with a whole lot.  Phasing into the shadows is fun but its annoying getting kicked out of the shadows when it seems like you should be fine.  At one point during the Merry-go-round, there was clearly open space that kept kicking me out of the shadows for no reason, and after going around and taking another route, it stopped doing it.  There's far more that could be done than simply putting boxes into the shadows, then moving the spotlight around.  Outside of getting kicked out of the shadows at random sometimes, the puzzles aren't overall too difficult to figure out once you pick out every option at your disposal.  The last stage introduces the idea to focus the spotlight but you cant keep it focused and is only used to raise a box higher and its only used once.  Its fairly useless to introduce something out of nowhere just to solve one puzzle, especially since you need to tell the player the controls so you're basically telling them what to do

On top of getting forced out of the shadows at odd times, the models for the shadows are clearly screwed up.  Johnny's hat is often floating half off of his head, the character's limbs seem to disconnect, and you can see glitches like this even with Dawn in the shadows.  It was most noticable when you had to float down on an umbrella and it disappeared whenever I faced a specific direction.

The game overall seemed a bit like Vincenzo's act in the end.  His act seemed cool but I could only see the shadows of it, and it was also over very quickly.  In fact, he seems to hint that there may be monsters in the Shadows that could prove to be an obstacle for Dawn but its never followed up on cause all thats left to do in the game is follow Didi then its over.  The game was very interesting, especially for the concept, but again, it only took 2 hours to complete.  Judging from the other reviews, it seems I may have gotten it down quickly, but in order to get 10 hours of gameplay, you would have to be looking for every luminary and every collectable, or have played through the game multiple times.  The game does have some good music and a good story, but its far too short and gameplay wise, not interesting enough to be worth the $17 (canadian) it costs normally.  I got it during a sale but even then, there's other games you could spend your money on instead
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Its a unique game, the shifting into the shadows gameplay is it's major selling point but it also has quite nice art, music and storyline.

As some of the other reviews hinted - everything in this game is really good but it's lacking some tiny bit of extra wowfactor which would really make it amazing.

I didn't find any terrible bugs.  But it does have issues, sort of like you would expect an infinite possibility sandbox environment to have issues.  It uses the dynamic shadows cast by the graphics engine as part of the gameplay, and sometimes that isn't going to work out right as there's just too many possible shadows that can be created.  I imagine it's damn near impossible to test properly as shadows can be different in a thousand ways.

The shadow play can be a bit annoying as you fall out of the shadows and back into the 3D world a little too easily.  And once (spoiler!) I shifted an item with me into the shadows and managed to lose it completely somewhere.. take care of your precious metal balls! :)

But anyway, the game is short and sweet, play it if you like unusual games.

reviewText: Ok I will make this quick and concise. This is a beautiful game, with great writing, solid ideal mechanics and a fun asthetic. But the coding is so bad. This game is not a puzzle game, often times you will figure out the puzzle then retry it 10-30 times because it's actually a near pixle perfect platformer, has completely unreliable physics which is what makes it maddening. I want to get involved with this story I dont want to try a jump 20 times in a row where it takes 10 times to figure out exactly when I have to jump to not drop out of shadow then another 10 to figure out what rotating object I have to get on that will get to the top. So if you are a patient person who loves old school platfpormers, you will like this game, if you are a story based person who likes solving puzzles this game will drive you crazy.

reviewText: Although a bit over-priced considering it being so short (I didn't stress through the game what-so-ever and still beat it in three hours) I recommend this game, but I would advice picking it up when it's on sale, since three hours for 14 euro is a bit on the expensive side. A beutifully designed game, with an engaging and sad little story about a young girl. Filled with economical issues, romantic affairs, mafia-involvement and drama.  With heavy elements of film noir, and with a graphic style that in many ways resembles a german expressionist silent film, with a touch of Tim Burton-esque quirkiness as the beutiful cherry on top. The humoristic elements such as hidden mature jokes really made me happy and sometimes I even laughed out loud. The puzzles are interesting, all though not that hard if you're used to puzzle-solving in games. But I still feel this game brought something new to the puzzle-genre. The gameplay mechanics are very well scripted and you quickly forget what buttons you have to click and just do it on impulse, immersed in the quirky little world that the game takes place in. Overall I really enjoyed this game, but it's far too short.

reviewText:
It's been a pleasure playing this game, but it has its flaws.
First, the bad notes: there are many tiny imperfections in the game that could be removed with little work, but in the context sound like a bad note in the symphony. Many times while moving in the shadows I was pushed out with no reason, like when passing over a semi-column in the lab; in many sections you can catch Didi in a T-pose, and even Dawn's position when using the umbrella is clearly a T-pose with an umbrella, and that really ruined the atmosphere.
But the game itself, especially for being a small production, is really good and enjoyable. The story is fascinating and, even if not the most suspence-filled noir plot, keeps you playing even just to know what's gonna happen. Deep characters and very nice voice-acting, the light-shadow system has it's flaws but its overall is quite good and fun. I bought the collector edition and I'm happy I did so, because the OST is very very nice. Finally, the way the game slowly shifts in a surrealist note is, at least for me, simply beautyful.
Maybe €15 are too many, but I recommend this game. You'll learn eventually that, if you stop demanding for extreme graphics and gory shootings, and start enjoying the little things, this game has a lot to offer.

You can tell there were several iterations of the story and they included pieces that don't entirely work together.  That said, the story is pretty good, if a bit disjointed.  Overall, I would recommend this game.  It definitely held my interest while I was playing it.

reviewText:
Now here's a unusual game.

I'm all about the story. For me a game can get away with average gameplay and a great story, but this game does well in both aspects, great story and great gameplay. Add to that the great artwork, a noir atmosphere, some sad jazz tunes, and you have a game worth keeping.
I'm still about halfway through (I suppose). But I've been hooked onto this game. You get to play a silent protagonist who can shift from the real world and into shadows. Shifting into a shadow makes you able to use shadows as a 2D platforms to traverse otherwise impossible to cross areas. You can use shadows as bridges or a sort of transportation device. In the real world (or should I say 3D), you get around just like any 3D platforming game. While in 3D mode you can move objects or light sources to arrange shadows in a way that could help you through some obstacles. The combination of 3D and 2D platforming make for interesting puzzles and a unique gameplay.
Definitely, a game worth buying, sale or no sale.

reviewText: Contrast is nothing short of a work of art. reviewText:
A stunning game. Brilliant concept backed up by some really nice graphics. The storyline is so engaging that I found it hard to put down. The puzzles were often a touch of genius. Not that they were difficult, only one or two stumped me and even then only for a short while. The genius is in the way they suck you into the story a little more each time. Especially the 'flashback' puzzles which can be tricky but never frustrating because the scene you are replaying is always a poignant moment in the story.
The soundtrack sets the tone just right and the voice acting is spot on. In particular Teale Bishopric was amazingly good as Didi.
Yes I have a few gripes. Jumping could be frustrating at times because it's a little to sensitive to collisions and it would have been nice to be able to customize the key mapping but that's about it.
It's a short game but one I will remember for a long time. I think it's almost the perfect length for the story. Yes I would have liked more but that's because I enjoyed it so much.

reviewText:
Warning this game is Short. it took me 2 hours to finish it and will probably only take me 30 or so minutes more to 100% it.

That being said. Holy Crap i love this game. The story is pretty straight forward, you are helping a little girl fix her fathers problems. In an attempt to get your family back together. There are some wholes in the story  that never get answered, but i don't think that this detracts from the game, unless you are purely here for the story and not the ability to jump in and out of shadows. Yes there is a lot left to be wanted on the story side, expecially in the ending, I was actually angry with how they cut it off. The game is still a great story.

Onto my favorite part of this game, its biggest attraction, shadow jumping (not what the game calls it). This is so much fun and its also just fun jumping in and out of shadows, using shadows as ramps. It is sad that the only real puzzles come up with focus mainly on the shadow world, yes you will have to manipulate things in the 3d world but everything boils down to how to move the shadows into the right place. I would have  liked it if there had been more need for puzzle solving in just the 2d world of the shadows and the 3d world, along with the ones that rely on both world. I feel that would have given me a more intimate experience with the world that the devs created.

I recommend this game, its short and sweet and has left me wanting more from this little universe that has so much personality in it. I am hoping and am wishing for a sequel, probably never going to happen.

reviewText:
A neat little indie with a cool gameplay hook, but Contrast falls short of its potential.  Contrast has a patchwerk story, which is incredibly unfortunate given the potential of the lore (it's visibly rushed despite a very interesting world).  I love the art style, and particularly love the 2D/3D platforming crossovers.  Contrast cleverly utilises intricate 3D world objects to affect the 2D world (to use a basic example that doesn't spoil the puzzles, dragging an item closer to the light to make the shadow on the wall bigger).  It has a 'cute' companion character and touches on some of the deeper issues surrounding families, but it only lasts about 2-3 hours on a slow playthrough.  I would say about 20-30 minutes of that focuses on the story, and the majority is spent trying to figure out the tricks for the puzzles.  Once you work them out, you could probably play from start to finish in less than an hour, without skipping.

There are two types of collectibles.  One type of collectible comes from exploring and overcoming optional puzzles, and is essentially useless outside of the few occasions you need them to progress (When you need them to progress, they're very easy to find).  The other works to build up the lore, and it's quite expansive.  These collectibles flesh out the story in much greater detail than the main storyline, but mostly they serve to highlight just how unfortunate it is that Contrast was cut short.

The pros:
An old-fashioned setting with a great accompanying visual style
Cool dynamics between 2D and 3D elements
Some deep themes around family
Clever use of mechanics in puzzles
Interesting lore

The cons:
Shallow and disjointed story, with a very rushed ending.
The majority of playtime and difficulty comes from initially working out puzzle styles
An irrelevant collection system (not referring to the lore collectibles)

The verdict:
Pick it up if you enjoy games with a sense of uniqueness, or the potential for depth (rather than depth itself).  Contrast will test your lateral thinking (though only on a few occasions), and it touches on some pretty cool concepts.

reviewText:
This game is pure art. Music, atmosphere, puzzles, story, it has everything. Beautifully created dreamlike world with story that will make you feel at some points like you are a little kid listening to bed time story and on other points game will draw you with it's seductive atmosphere of film noir.

It will take you from 6-8 hrs to go slowly throgh the game, and this is just enough for unique experience this game brings to the world of gaming.

Puzzles are very interesting and very fun to complete. Had no problem finishing any of them, even those that are obvious to solve, I still enjoyed perfect execution of puzzles that are many times used much more for story telling than to flex your brain.

Music...music is story for itself...so good that I re-discovered whole femme fatal and smooth jazz genre once again.

In short: Beautiful experience, worth buying at full price.

reviewText:
In my opinion, Contrast is a great game that I enjoyed very much.

Pros:
+ Very clever gameplay, shift between 2D and 3D is quite smooth and makes a lot of fun to play
+ Beautiful story, suitable for children
+ Lovely atmosphere of the 1920s, nice graphics
+ Great music
+ For me: Reasonable controls that I had no problems with (in contrast to other opinions here)

Cons:
- Really rather short game
- Steam Achievments are to easy, no real challenge

In conclusion, I would not recommend it on full price, but only because it is too short. When it is on sale, you should definitly grab it instantly. I got some magical hours out of it that simply made me feel happier.
9/10
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Took me 9 hours to finish and find all collectibles and all Steam achievements. If you're used to this kind of game it might take even less, so maybe some people will probably think the game is too short.  Except for collectibles and achievements you probably won't play it more than once... However I see it as reading a short novel in a very interactive way. So if I'd pay for a book that would maybe take me 8 or 9 hours to read (and that I wouldn't read again too soon), why not pay for a game as fun as this one? I loved the story and how it unfolded.
The puzzles in the beginning are very easy, but later start getting harder. Since it's a short game I definitely don't recommend reading/watching walkthroughs. The feeling of accomplishment in a game like this one is important and puzzles ARE reasonable.
The only time I watched a walkthrough was in a part when I was sure there had to be a way to move a light beam and that that would help me find the solution, but I wasn't able to move it. I confirmed that that was the case and figured out by myself that I had to use the mouse (as when moving the camera) because of some probable incompatibility with the controller.
So, two hints (no spoilers) you might need that for me were not that obvious and got me stuck for a long while:
- Sometimes you have to get very near something to interact with it.
- If you use a controller, you might still need to use the mouse every now and then to move the camera and light beams.
Other than that, I got no issues with the game. The atmosphere reminds me of Grim Fandango, one of my favorite games of all times!
I strongly recommend this game.

reviewText:
This is an excellent puzzle exploration game with an interesting storyline if you watch cut-scenes.

What makes this game a trendsetting gem, though, is that the developers have conceptualized progression problem solving in a completely new way. It's unique to see a game that features a dual-dimensional landscape that requires players to use the character's ability to fluidly shift between the 2-D and 3-D environments to solve various puzzles and progress.

The game can be successfully conquered in a couple hours and aside from a few bugs here and there and infrequent save points, it's a good game that doesn't require a lifetime of dedication to fully complete *cough* Skyrim *cough*. I got my copy for $15 and I'd say that price is appropriate.

reviewText:
Contrast was a beautiful game to play. The noir style was very well done. The story was engaging and the game mechanic was novel and fun to play with.

Controlling Dawn could be a bit twitchy at times. The camera sits behind Dawn and it felt like directional control was connected to Dawn not the camera. Since the camera is placed so far behind her a small turn of Dawn translated into a huge pan of the camera. It was very jarring initially.

The end felt like it came out of nowhere. The first two acts felt like one cohesive story line while the third act felt like it was half the original story with a sudden shift to a different one.

Contrast feels a little like Portal 1 in the sense that it's the developer's first time out with a new mechanic. Hopefully there will be a second one, it'd give the developers a chance to really perfect the mechanic and develop another set of really interesting puzzles.

reviewText:
So... Contrast.

The short version is this: great soundtrack, decent game, decent story, way too short and the ending is a bit rushed and predictable.

The longer version is this: I personally really enjoyed the game.  The style of the game was really well done.  Some of the mechanics were interesting, such as using the shadows of people in conversation to reach a new location.  That said, the ending really did feel a bit rushed, and, assuming you find a few of the (extremely easy to find) collectibles, extremely easy to predict.  Would I recommend it?  For $15, definitely; I think I paid $20 for the pre-order + soundtrack, which I'm still okay with, considering I'm a sucker for this style of music and atmosphere.

Anyway, if you've got $15 to spare, support some indie devs and give it a shot.

reviewText:
Contrast is a very well-done and innovative Indie game. It falls into the puzzle genre, but utilizes first-person character control and does require a bit of speed.

Like all games, Contrast has its merits and pitfalls. Some things I really liked about the game are:
- A very well-thought-out and touching story
- Beautiful soundtrack (especially Kat's Song". Youtube it!)
- A unique gameplay mechanic
- Some decently challenging puzzles
- Beautifully done art. Many noir games and movies nowadays are just creepy and Sin City-like. This is a much more refreshing take on the noir theme.

And some things that weren't so great:
- I don't know anyone who has clocked more than 10 hours to beat this
- Some minor bugs
- a reference to Albert Einstein in an earlier time period (learn your history
recommended: Contrast is very well-done and a must-buy for any Indie fan. People who liked story-intensive games such as Bastion will definitely enjoy Contrast more than most. Of course $15 for a game this short may pinch wallets
hoursPlayed: so do wait for a sale. And of course
voteText: we hope to hear of a second game from Compulsion Studios soon. =D"

reviewText: Contrast use of light and shadow mixed with the beautiful music and ambiance make it a game well worth the price. The idea of the game is simple, complete the objective. Although the approach is different and the gameplay is not perfect the effect and emotions portrayed by the character and the abstract realism make this game shine. The voice actors did a remarkable job with the script they were given as well. While the creators could have shown the world from our view, using dawns perspective allowed for them to cut the out all of the extras that would have dragged the game down such as rendering multiple characters and dressing them differently. The artistic use of a disintegrating world aspect allowed for the playable area to be clearly marked while still aesthetically pleasing. The only downfall that is apparent is the length of the game. A sequel to this game or possible a franchise would definantly get my money. Hopefully in the sequel will be longer and the characters mouths will move.

reviewText:
The shadow mechanic provides a great hook for this game, setting it apart from other platformers.  It's not a perfect mechanic, however, as I've sometimes found myself trapped in little nooks, crannies, and corners.  It can also be a bit glitchy/frustrating when a jump or action looks perfectly feasible, and your timing and positioning are perfect, but the game just doesn't want to register it correctly.

These are pretty minor concerns, and detract little from the game overall.  The story is fantastic, as are the characters.  The music is top-notch, and the visuals in general are very rich and atmospheric, setting the mood very well.

My only other complaint is the game's length, as it is too short.  I understand the reasons behind this, but am disappointed nonetheless.  I would love to see some DLC or a sequel in the future, as this was a terrific game.

reviewText: A very charming puzzle-platformer with a very impressive motif and soundtrack. The story of the game largely revolves around a broken family trying to piece itself together and is at its best when it focuses on their trials and tribulations. (It takes a weird turn near the end trying to answer questions I never asked about the broken shadow dimension that protagonist Dawn inhabits that just end up raising even more questions, but that treads into spoiler territory.) Manipulating shadows so that Dawn can become a shadow and platform across them proved to be an interesting challenge that had me scratching my head more than a few times, and they were never afraid of introducing new elements (even if some of those elements involved box-switch puzzles seen in many games before). The game is definitely a bit on the short side, however, and the only thing that kept me from clearing it 100% on my first run was a few collectibles and one item that was only available for a short time frame and ended up being lost forever. It's also very story-focused, and relies heavily on cutscenes to tell its tale. Overall, it's definitely flawed (probably rushed a bit to be a PS4 launch title), but it's an enjoyable game that should be tried.

reviewText: Coming away from Contrast after some thought – it’s come to me that this is a game that I enjoyed more for its theme. I stuck with the game for its amazing setting, lovely soundtrack and to see the end of the story, rather than staying for its 3D-to-2D shifting gameplay. The shortness of the game means that the puzzle mechanics are never given the time to fully grow. Mix this up with some questionable glitches and you’re left with a game that isn’t as well constructed as one would like.\n\nContrast is a curious, fair attempt at a puzzle platformer with some neat ideas that make it somewhat enjoyable, but is a slightly frustrating experience that in the end won’t be remembered for its gameplay, but more for its world, visuals and sound.

reviewText:
Beautiful, fun little game. Unfortunately it's only about three hours long.
Perhaps a little longer if you really try to get all the collectables.
The 2D shadow mechanic is done really well. It's not a difficult game and you can mess up as often as you like. Ideal for people that are actually quite bad at platforming, such as myself.

Personally, I wanted more from this game. It's short and so it doesn't drag on, but on the other hand it feels like only the surface of both the story and the mechanics is seen.
Only at the very end of the game does it feel comfortable making you take leaps of faith and fulling combining the 2D and 3D puzzles.
I really hope there will be a sequel. I just didn't get enough from this.

TL;DR:
Great game, fun puzzles and easy platforming. Good for a casual 3 hours of gameplay.
Beautiful enviroment and good story.

reviewText:
A neat little indie with a cool gameplay hook, but Contrast falls short of its potential.  Contrast has a patchwerk story, which is incredibly unfortunate given the potential of the lore (it's visibly rushed despite a very interesting world).  I love the art style, and particularly love the 2D/3D platforming crossovers.  Contrast cleverly utilises intricate 3D world objects to affect the 2D world (to use a basic example that doesn't spoil the puzzles, dragging an item closer to the light to make the shadow on the wall bigger).  It has a 'cute' companion character and touches on some of the deeper issues surrounding families, but it only lasts about 2-3 hours on a slow playthrough.  I would say about 20-30 minutes of that focuses on the story, and the majority is spent trying to figure out the tricks for the puzzles.  Once you work them out, you could probably play from start to finish in less than an hour, without skipping.

There are two types of collectibles.  One type of collectible comes from exploring and overcoming optional puzzles, and is essentially useless outside of the few occasions you need them to progress (When you need them to progress, they're very easy to find).  The other works to build up the lore, and it's quite expansive.  These collectibles flesh out the story in much greater detail than the main storyline, but mostly they serve to highlight just how unfortunate it is that Contrast was cut short.

The pros:
An old-fashioned setting with a great accompanying visual style
Cool dynamics between 2D and 3D elements
Some deep themes around family
Clever use of mechanics in puzzles
Interesting lore

The cons:
Shallow and disjointed story, with a very rushed ending.
The majority of playtime and difficulty comes from initially working out puzzle styles
An irrelevant collection system (not referring to the lore collectibles)

The verdict:
Pick it up if you enjoy games with a sense of uniqueness, or the potential for depth (rather than depth itself).  Contrast will test your lateral thinking (though only on a few occasions), and it touches on some pretty cool concepts.

However... for the flaws, this game was really enjoyable. It's a bit of soul food, makes you think and ask questions. It feels substantial as far as the story and the world is concerned (Some say gameplay is lacking challange, but for me it lacked a lot of the frustration that can come with some puzzle games with obtuse solutions. For example, the secret star solutions in Braid, one of which requires you to do nothing but wait for nearly 40 minutes or so). The art is fantastic, definitely different from what i've played recently. The Music and overal sound design is wonderful, though the voice acting isn't the best.

Contrast is one of those examples of Games are Art" while still being a game

reviewText:
Contrast is a game that grows on you and leaves you wanting more.
The play style (Shadow shifting) for solving puzzles and progressing forward makes this game really fun.
Although alot of elements were done before in various other titles, they were never done this good.

The puzzles aren't too hard either so even the most novice players will get through them when stretching some brain muscles.

The story slowly sucks you in from start to finish giving you just enough clues to keep you hanging on a threat but never enough to give it's story fully away.

There were some clipping and frame rate issues here and there but was minor enough not to take up arms over it.

I'd recommend this game to the young and old, hard-core puzzle fanatics or novices.
Go on... give it a try... and enjoy.  :3

reviewText:
When I saw Contrast at Steam Greenlight I knew that was a title I was going to play.
Those who know me will easily understand why: Contrast has female protagonists, something I'm always looking forward to,  beautiful character and environment design, with an aesthetic close to my heart, an interesting mechanic and was non-violent, which is something I'm beginning to appreciate, even though I love to hack and slash things.
So, as soon as it was available for pre-order, I decided to buy it, even if I was not at my best financially. It was worth it.
First, the whole game was translated to brazilian portuguese, with the exception of the audio (which would've been really costly). Although I have no problem understanding english, this was a nice touch, specially when most people at my country don't have easy access to english lessons. Second, the game is beautiful, entertaining and interesting. I almost gasped at the final revelation: something I thought to be just an aesthetic choice, in the end, had much more meaning within the story.
The puzzles were difficult enough to keep me interested, not hard to the point of making me want to give up nor easy to the point of leaving me bored. I once or twice thought of looking through a walkthrough, 'cause I'm lazy and always craving for more pieces of information surrounding a game's story, but I'd always close the window and decide to solve the puzzle myself. I loved when you activated some sort of memory" and interacted with the shadows.
There were glitches and bugs
date: like getting stuck between shadow-world and "real-world"
recommended: but nothing really troubling.\nThe controls were a bit weird at the beginning
hoursPlayed: I felt like Dawn walked too fast or something
voteText: but I got used to it quickly.  I could complain that the game is short. It is
helpfulPercent: really
votesHelpful: but I honestly think it's worth it. It's an engaging experience and I think it lasts enough.  My only true complaint is that sometimes the cut-scenes would break the pace of the game. You'd walk a bit or solve one short puzzle and have a cut-scene right after it in a way that felt a tiny bit out of place. In the beginning of the game I felt there were too many short cut-scenes happening all the time.\nStill
votesTotal: it's not something that takes anything out of this wonderful game. This is a game you can show your non-gamer friends and family members too and I think would grab their attention. If you are open to it
votesFunny: you could ask them to help solving some puzzles
commentsCount: to make them engage more with the game.\nVisuals are lovely
column16: gameplay is nice and the story is interesting.\nI'd recommend it for sure.\n"

reviewText:
In the end everybody should stand up and give a round of applause, so impressive and nicely done.

The mechanics through entering the shadows and having to exit creates such awesome puzzles.
Gameplay and graphics are well done, actually much more than that.

However the masterpiece in this game is the soundtrack, FABULOUS. When I first opened the game while hearing the song over the menu, really, that was an awesome sensation. It was literally music to my ears and this high level of soundtrack keeps going during all the game.

I don't know if it is kind of a spoiler but at first I was like in doubt in the first scene where Didi is in her room and her mom appears through the shadows, but that makes sense over the ending.

Only a few issues with my controller that would not jump in certain occasions that would soon enough become normal.(I think the problem really is in my controller not really how the game adapted it, but...)

Only a few bugs with the character and the scenario, nothing like would destroy the game, because it doesn't even affect the gameplay (like the carousel would spin and the character stands still).

The studio created their own style, of course people will compare it limbo (black and white through the shadows) and I still don't know why but gave me a déjà vu of bioshock infinite like the theory from multiverse and portals used between shadows, people will say that somehow the appearance of Dawn remembers Elizabeth and the city is in the sky?(That's what it looks like to me).

Congratulations for the studio and keep the hard work to develop others great pieces of art like these. (And let me know about it, I would love to play again any other creation).

reviewText: While I recommend this game for its tremendous style, awesome soundtrack and clever concept, I feel there are two warnings for prospective buyers. First, a skilled player can probably complete it, achievements and all, in about two hours. In this day and age of hundred hour rpgs and unlimited online play, some may feel this affects the value. Secondly, there were times when I really felt that the controls didn't work as they should and I found it very frustrating. I'm not the best at platformers by a long shot, but I feel like their were times I missed jumps and it really wasn't my fault.\nOverall, I would say this game is like a short art film. It oozes style and tells a sweet, albeit simple story. Wonderful to experience, I think anyone who made it so far as reading this review should pick it up, because the factors that likely drew them to this point are all there and in spades.

reviewText:
Contrast is a very well-done and innovative Indie game. It falls into the puzzle genre, but utilizes first-person character control and does require a bit of speed.

Like all games, Contrast has its merits and pitfalls. Some things I really liked about the game are:
- A very well-thought-out and touching story
- Beautiful soundtrack (especially Kat's Song". Youtube it!)
- A unique gameplay mechanic
- Some decently challenging puzzles
- Beautifully done art. Many noir games and movies nowadays are just creepy and Sin City-like. This is a much more refreshing take on the noir theme.

And some things that weren't so great:
- I don't know anyone who has clocked more than 10 hours to beat this
- Some minor bugs
- a reference to Albert Einstein in an earlier time period (learn your history
recommended: Contrast is very well-done and a must-buy for any Indie fan. People who liked story-intensive games such as Bastion will definitely enjoy Contrast more than most. Of course $15 for a game this short may pinch wallets
hoursPlayed: so do wait for a sale. And of course
voteText: we hope to hear of a second game from Compulsion Studios soon. =D"

reviewText: Contrast use of light and shadow mixed with the beautiful music and ambiance make it a game well worth the price. The idea of the game is simple, complete the objective. Although the approach is different and the gameplay is not perfect the effect and emotions portrayed by the character and the abstract realism make this game shine. The voice actors did a remarkable job with the script they were given as well. While the creators could have shown the world from our view, using dawns perspective allowed for them to cut the out all of the extras that would have dragged the game down such as rendering multiple characters and dressing them differently. The artistic use of a disintegrating world aspect allowed for the playable area to be clearly marked while still aesthetically pleasing. The only downfall that is apparent is the length of the game. A sequel to this game or possible a franchise would definantly get my money. Hopefully in the sequel will be longer and the characters mouths will move.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
The shadow mechanic provides a great hook for this game, setting it apart from other platformers.  It's not a perfect mechanic, however, as I've sometimes found myself trapped in little nooks, crannies, and corners.  It can also be a bit glitchy/frustrating when a jump or action looks perfectly feasible, and your timing and positioning are perfect, but the game just doesn't want to register it correctly.

These are pretty minor concerns, and detract little from the game overall.  The story is fantastic, as are the characters.  The music is top-notch, and the visuals in general are very rich and atmospheric, setting the mood very well.

My only other complaint is the game's length, as it is too short.  I understand the reasons behind this, but am disappointed nonetheless.  I would love to see some DLC or a sequel in the future, as this was a terrific game.

reviewText:
Contrast is one of those games that has a good premise - the idea of use light and shadows to create a separate bit of 2D puzzle gameplay from the normal 3D world, but the implementation from a story and setting as well as design is a bit disconnected.  The technical approach is good in how you can shift in an our of shadows, but the problem is that the areas you can do this in are very limited and separated from each other, making each puzzle its own microcosm.   The puzzles that use this aren't that difficult as well, with the most difficult ones being where you can either move objects to change shadows or the location of the light source. Again, with the puzzles being separate entities, these are one-stop problems as opposed to part of a larger difficult mechanism to figure out.

The story is interesting but it's hard to get into and leaves some questions on getting into the characters. Whether this is a fantasy, a dream, or something else isn't clear, and whether it is a flashback or the like.  As such, the game quickly devolves into just moving from puzzle to puzzle with story getting in the way.

It is still a decent game, but it's one I'd wait for a sale for, getting about 3 hrs of playtime from it.

Over all  The controlls where excellent, a little sticky here and there in certain spot probably from my own doing.
There are a few spots in the game though if you lose a critical piece to the puzzle you must killl yourself to restart that part to get that critical piece back.  It was kind of annoying to have to jump off a ledge to respawn a box that I needed to have for a very small part of a leve.
Overall the visuall are fantastic, the use of light and shadows are amazing and it takes into effect 2D planes.
Over all if you want to kill a few hours with a very good puzzle game I would download this, But due to the shortness of the game I would suggest to buy it on a sale or give it to a friend when it goes on sale.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A living embodiment of 3d puzzle combined with the 2D style platformer such that of Limbo. The atmosphere of the game set around the 1920's with its Jazzy influences and the developments of magic shows really opened up a spectacular mystery genre to the art of the game. For a few moments, the game looked easy and only required persistence to get through levels, but eventually requiring more brainwork than eye hand coordination as the levels progressed in acts II and III. What seemed like a memory of the protagonist, Didi, becomes a reality in this magical game of shadows and their players.

Overall, one of those masterpieces of 2013 if only the game wasn't so heavy on a simple graphics card!
9/10

reviewText:
This is probably one of the best puzzle games I've played. If you have any liking for French jazz culture, this is the game for you. It is all about using light in creative ways to solve puzzles, most of which are platforming.

My favorite pieces are the music which was put together with care. The vocalist they hired to sing a couple songs has the perfect voice for this type of jazz. All of the voice acting is quite solid. The other piece that drew me in was the use of shadows to represent characters rather than physical beings. I think that is explained through collectibles, but I haven't spent much time with it. Contrast also manages to portray a sense of innocence surrounding Didi while giving some very adult conflicts when she's not around.

The only real issue I had was with either the controls or the design, I'm not sure. Sometimes when something seemed easy to accomplish, like a jump, you'd be force off the wall for some reason and have to start over. Basically I think some of the shadows in the environment were unintentional and created surprise blocks for you to avoid. It could also just be I'm not very practiced at platformers. The puzzles seem well designed and not too challenging to figure out. After figuring out what needs to be done, you may still need to take a few tries at it before succeeding, but it isn't usually too frustrating.

It is quite a short game if you figure out the puzzles quickly, it took me maybe 6 hours. So I probably wouldn't buy it for full price just because of the length, but I would definitely buy it on sale. Also, the soundtrack is a great jazz compilation.

One last note: at I believe the end of the first act, there are two endings depending on if you just stand and watch, or actively do something (I don't want to give spoilers) If you don't do anything, you'll fail the level and be put back to the beginning of the dialogue, so I recommend just listening first, then actually doing what you're supposed to.

reviewText:
In a world seperate from ours, but connected through shadows; you play as Dawn. A mysterious companion to a little girl. With your special shadow shifiting powers; you will help her reunite her family.
Looking for a short puzzle adventure as a break from your usual gaming? Look no farther than Contrast!

With a brilliant/beautiful graphical art style, intriguing gameplay mechanics, and a beautiful soundtrack; you will not be disappointed.
The only downside is the puzzles are very simple and easy to solve, so there is no difficulty anywhere in the game.

I bought this game on the Steam Summer sale for only $10, but it is definitely worth the full asking price.

So go ahead, buy it already!

reviewText:
‘Constrast’ is a game of the platformer variety, centred around a puzzle mechanic which uses light and shadows as a mean of switching between a 3D and 2D environment, but it becomes completely irredeemable by committing the capital sin for platformers : bad controls. The game simply doesn’t work at what it is trying to do and, as such, is utterly unrecommendable.

It starts… bad, and only gets worse. The game has no rebindable keys, the mouse cursor doesn’t work in every menu (like restarting a checkpoint or leaving the game), but it does offer very lacklustre graphic options. Although I like the style of the game, I really disliked its graphics quality. The textures aren’t pretty, and there is nothing to distract from them, as the environments are lifeless and empty. Even the music doesn’t help, as it is barely even present while you are exploring or solving puzzles. Worse, one of the main mechanics of the game requires you to play with shadows, but even they are barebones at best. In the days of soft focus shadows, that’s a big no-no if your main mechanic revolves around them. All the cutscenes and story bits are shown through the shadows too, so you get to experience bad graphics on top of very stick figure-like animations, not even remotely human. Not that it really matters as the story holds no water, but I will get to that in a minute.
But alright, let’s give it the benefit of the doubt, what else is there? Any other nitpicks? Well, even though I’m a native French speaker, I preferred the English dub, but the collectibles, with press articles and other, supposedly, world building information extracts, aren’t fully translated! That’s disappointing.

What about the gameplay? Well, the controls aren’t rebindable, the camera is atrocious, -which doesn’t help-, and the animation of the character is stiff and “mechanic”. Clunky really, fast and yet without precision. When the camera switches mode, between locked in 2D shadow world and free 3D exploration, it is feels horrible: during the transitions, it is either too quick or too slow, but feels unnatural either way, jarring. You don’t feel in control, you are at the mercy of the game’s whims.
So let me get this straight. It is a puzzle platformer with bad controls and bad camera, where you have to jump on platforms made from poorly rendered shadows, from which you will end up sliding off for the smallest offense. This will lead to some frustration since… well, you character doesn’t move like you want it to or the game just refuses to acknowledge your input, for whatever reason, and getting sacked for it, unfairly, is rather infuriating. It is actually so bad, I landed in a secret area one time, one I hadn’t neither seen nor planned on jumping into. Thanks for that I guess, but it isn’t gonna make up for all the bad jump related deaths.

As said before, even the story didn’t hold my attention. In all honesty, I had a hard time sympathizing with the dad figure. Because he was trying, although he put his family in harm’s way, that makes every alright? When you stand in the rain, you get wet. Don’t. Stand. In. The. Rain. Or least, don’t ask for my sympathy when you complain about getting drenched. The story didn’t resonate with me.

The nail in the coffin was one particular moment that is reminiscent of Limbo. Except, you know, Limbo kind of works. So now I have a better game in my mind that I could be playing on top of all this nonsense. Anyway, it was too obvious, with the spider and all… You haven’t earned that game, the right to make an ‘homage’ like that. And even if you did, you have a game that is three hours short (and thank god for that! I wouldn’t have been able to play any more of it), and you basically have so little to put in it that you lift levels from another game. That doesn’t come across as very endearing to me.

There is definitely an interesting concept at the core of the game, with the change between 3D and 2D platformer, and that’s where the puzzles are I suppose, if you can call them that. It is a proof of concept, sure, but that’s not enough for a good game. And it is actually possible to break the puzzles, making them impossible to solve, forcing you to reload if you aren’t careful enough, which you can’t be because of the horrendous controls! At times, it does feel like an endless cycle of displeasure. Certainly, that concept deserved better. As it stands, the game is a demo I would present to my boss in order to get funding for a project based around the shown concept, not a final product I would charge money for.

All in all, what I am seeing here is a game that had a great gameplay concept, and a great art style, but failed to get to the finish line with them. The game feels rushed, empty in a lot of aspect, barely functional sometimes, without any form of polish whatsoever, and it makes it all the more disappointing when the game does finally decide to work, when, very rarely, there are some “sparks” and it clicks. From time to time, things work out alright, and the puzzles and their solutions aren’t hampered by the flaws of the game, but those shining moments, where the transition from an open world to one of shadows stimulates your brain and gives you the satisfaction of actually solving a problem in a clever way, without the frustration of dealing with force outside your reach, are far too few to justify any consideration of purchase, no matter the price.

reviewText:
Yes, i recommend it, but just not at full price. In a 50% off sale, you can consider.

Contrast is a game that has catched my attention because of its innovative game mechanics, those mechanics are really cool and area a good refreshment. You can classify its gameplay as a platformermer/puzzle game, thoug its puzzle are not hard (unless it bugs). The game charachters are really nice, especially Dawn, but they could be a bit deeper. I think the innovative mechanics could be more explored, and the charachters could gain more depht. The game is really short (it took me 6 hours to beat it and i'm usually slow) and buggy. There are bugs everywhere, some parts of the game are not hard, but you can't complete them because something bugs and makes it more difficult than it should be (stuck on a wall, gone through it, etc). Other complaint is the camera wich could be better placed, because sometimes it makes difficult for you to jump.
Though I said a lot of negative points, i recommend Contrast for its inovative mechanics and its nice story.

6.8/10

reviewText:
This game was quite odd. As a game its nothing special; it would even be fair to say its gameplay is just bad. I often felt as though I tricked trough some levels by takng advantage of the hit-and-miss gameplay like making jumps that would avoid the puzzles. The stories execution is equally questionable, with a protagonist who serves to guide you through the game without any real finesse. And by that I don't mean your character; you seem to serve more as a tool for her tasks but that is the point.

TO THE GOOD!

This game had a very specific feel about it which I felt made it worth playing. The art style and music marry so well together that I forgave the shaky gameplay (at least for the most part). Depite its dodgy execution, I got what it was trying to show and it made for an enjoyable experience. The story wasn't as linear as what I've come to expect; whether thats a good or bad thing, im not entirely sure. Its fair to say Didi (the young girl) was a bit 'pushy' in trying to force you into the story, but I didnt really mind as my character is there to help her and the interactions of the character felt right for the situation.

Theres plenty to find out beyond the game through exploration. I actually think these bits were what made the game as it added another level of story beyond Didi's life to something more personal for the character Dawn (who never speaks IIRC), also - great name without being something cheesy. I would throughly recommend you endevour to find the 20(I think?) hidden media snippets! It reminded me of Bioshock in that the information you find explains the situation youre in; but in a modest way.

This game however is by no means difficult! I did the entire story in a single 2 hour sitting and found everything in that time. This wasn't even deliberately to finish it, I just felt like the game never lost traction and felt so, almost, calm to play that I kept casually playing. This isnt to say the story was good; it was weak with the hidden snippets making it interesting but it was solid enough in terms of character and situation.

Overall, as someone who does try to game as much as possible, I can't honestly say its a great game. But for me, it was incredibly playable and I will revisit it again gladly. It was like listening to music, I did indeed just easily loose track of time and do it. I found it quite charming if I'm being honest.

I played it with a controller if that means anything? You wont need the precision or focus of a kb+m but thats just my preference for this game. I would also say if youre on the fence about it, its probably best you wait till a sale comes around. I don't think I paid full price and despite enjoying it, don't know if its worth it. Definately feels like it should be £6.99 or similarly priced. Wouldn't be upset if I did pay retail though.

reviewText:
This is probably one of the best puzzle games I've played. If you have any liking for French jazz culture, this is the game for you. It is all about using light in creative ways to solve puzzles, most of which are platforming.

My favorite pieces are the music which was put together with care. The vocalist they hired to sing a couple songs has the perfect voice for this type of jazz. All of the voice acting is quite solid. The other piece that drew me in was the use of shadows to represent characters rather than physical beings. I think that is explained through collectibles, but I haven't spent much time with it. Contrast also manages to portray a sense of innocence surrounding Didi while giving some very adult conflicts when she's not around.

The only real issue I had was with either the controls or the design, I'm not sure. Sometimes when something seemed easy to accomplish, like a jump, you'd be force off the wall for some reason and have to start over. Basically I think some of the shadows in the environment were unintentional and created surprise blocks for you to avoid. It could also just be I'm not very practiced at platformers. The puzzles seem well designed and not too challenging to figure out. After figuring out what needs to be done, you may still need to take a few tries at it before succeeding, but it isn't usually too frustrating.

It is quite a short game if you figure out the puzzles quickly, it took me maybe 6 hours. So I probably wouldn't buy it for full price just because of the length, but I would definitely buy it on sale. Also, the soundtrack is a great jazz compilation.

One last note: at I believe the end of the first act, there are two endings depending on if you just stand and watch, or actively do something (I don't want to give spoilers) If you don't do anything, you'll fail the level and be put back to the beginning of the dialogue, so I recommend just listening first, then actually doing what you're supposed to.

reviewText: This is easily one of the best games I've ever played, maybe even the best.\nContrast is an amazing puzzle game, that makes you think about any little thing inside that might help you. Altough it is not a game that fills up alot of your time to complete, the artwork is fantastic and the story really puls you in. The few bucks that it cost to buy this game is money well spend.\nI am really looking forward to an expention or a second part of the game!!

reviewText:
A clever but underachieving adventure / puzzle game elevated at times by an interesting setting and story.
For those of you that don't know, your character can blend between 3d person and 2d projected platforming by stepping into the light projected onto walls. Shadows become walls, floors and even lifts to new areas. At its best it feels like a mix of fez and portal, but at its worst the shadow stepping can be awkward and unreliable.
The pacing is acceptable and there seem to be multiple ways to approach some puzzles, but there's no serious challenge here.
The setting falls somewhere between Bugsy Malone and Alice in Wonderland, but doesn't fully deliver on either. The noir story is a nice touch, but not gritty enough for my tastes, and whilst the worlds warp and float like a fever dream this fact is entirely ignored by the characters. I would not have been shocked to see: But it was all a dream. The End"
There were some beautiful moments towards the end of the game where a deeper meaning is hinted
